questions.questionText: What will happen if in a C program you assign a value to an array element whose subscript exceeds the size of array?

options.text: The element will be set to 0.
The compiler would report an error.
The array size would appropriately grow.
The program may crash if some important data gets overwritten.

questions.questionText: Which of the following statements is correct in C++?

options.text: Classes cannot have data as protected members.
Structures can have functions as members.
Class members are public by default.
Structure members are private by default.

questions.questionText: What do the following declaration signify? char *arr[10];

options.text: arr is a array of function pointer.
arr is a array of 10 character pointers.
arr is a array of characters.
arr is a pointer to array of characters.
Should be called when an object is destroyed
Can be called using the class name and function
Is closely connected with an individual object of a class
Is used when a dummy object must be created

questions.questionText: In which stage the following code #include<stdio.h> gets replaced by the contents of the file stdio.h

options.text: During preprocessing
During editing
During linking
During execution

questions.questionText: What happens when a class with parameterized constructors and having no default constructor is used in a program and we create an object that needs a zero-argument constructor?

options.text: Preprocessing error.
Runtime error.
Runtime exception.
Compile-time error.

questions.questionText: Which of the following cannot be checked in a switch-case statement?

options.text: Character
Float
Integer
enum

questions.questionText: What is the correct way to create an object called myObj of MyClass?

options.text: MyClass myObj;
new myObj = MyClass();
class myObj = new MyClass();
class MyClass = new myObj();

questions.questionText: What is the similarity between a structure, union and enumeration?

options.text: All of them let you define new data types
All of them let you define new values
All of them let you define new pointers
All of them let you define new structures

while x > y:
